description: BRISTOL- Noah Gragson took home the victory in the NASCAR Xfinity Series at Bristol Motor Speedway and left his JR Motorsports teammate Justin Allgaier fuming. With the race on the line, Gragson drove his No. 9 Chevrolet to the inside of Allgaier's No. 7 Chevy with five laps to go. Gragson then held off a challenge from Chase Briscoe and Brandon Jones in an overtime...
text:
BRISTOL \- Noah Gragson took home the victory in the NASCAR Xfinity Series at
Bristol Motor Speedway and left his JR Motorsports teammate Justin Allgaier
fuming.

With the race on the line, Gragson drove his No. 9 Chevrolet to the inside of
Allgaier's No. 7 Chevy with five laps to go. The two cars made contact as
Gragson drove on with the lead and Allgaier slammed into the outside wall.

Gragson then held off a challenge from Chase Briscoe and Brandon Jones in an
overtime finish for his second win of the season and of his career.

"I really apologize to Justin and his team. That's not how I want to race,"
Gragson said. "I saw that position open up when he slipped off the bottom. I
tried to get to the bottom and I just got too loose. This track was like ice.
Everyone was slipping and sliding."

Gragson, a 21-year-old from Las Vegas, won the final two stages of the race
and led two times for 55 laps. He hadn't finished higher than ninth in five
previous Bristol starts in the Xfinity and Truck Series.

"We had been terrible here in Trucks and then in Xfinity last year," Gragson
said. "My crew chief (David Elenz) believed in me. He wanted me to come back
and run with them this season."

Allgaier won Stage 1 of the race and led 156 laps overall. It was the third
Bristol race in a row that he led the most laps and failed to win. He left the
track after the race without a post-race interview.

Briscoe held on for second with Jones third and pole-sitter Harrison Burton
fourth. Each of the top four finishers qualified for a chance to win a
$100,000 Dash 4 Cash bonus in Saturday's race at Atlanta.

It was the second straight runner-up finish at Bristol for Briscoe, driver of
the No. 98 Stewart-Haas Racing Ford.

"We had a fifth- or sixth-place car most of the night," Briscoe said. "We were
really tight. There at the end, restarts went our way and we were able to
salvage second."

Myatt Snider rounded out the top five in a Chevrolet. The rest of the top 10
were all in Chevys with Daniel Hemric sixth, followed by Brandon Brown, Jeremy
Clements, Josh Williams and A.J. Allmendinger.

LOCAL CONNECTIONS

Knoxville driver Chad Finchum finished 24th in the No. 13 Toyota. The former
Kingsport Speedway champion was 10th early in Stage 2 before having mechanical
problems. Jesse Little, driving the No. 4 Visit Kingsport Chevrolet, ran in
the top 15 early and finished 26th.

NASCAR STATEMENT

NASCAR released a statement Monday concerning the recent deaths that have
sparked protests and riots in the following days.

It read, "The NASCAR family, like so many others, is hurt and angered by the
immensely troubling events that have taken place across our country in recent
weeks. For us to heal and move forward as a nation, we all need to listen more
and be united in the stand against racism, hatred, senseless violence and loss
of life. And we must all hold ourselves accountable to driving positive
change.

"While our sport has made progress over the years, there remains much work to
be done and we fully embrace our responsibility to help bridge the racial
divide that continues to exist in our country. We must do better and our
commitment to promoting equality and inclusion continues and will never
waver."

title: Gragson dashes to Xfinity win as teammate crashes at Bristol
html:
BRISTOL - Noah Gragson took home the victory in the NASCAR Xfinity Series at Bristol Motor Speedway and left his JR Motorsports teammate Justin Allgaier fuming.

With the race on the line, Gragson drove his No. 9 Chevrolet to the inside of Allgaier's No. 7 Chevy with five laps to go. The two cars made contact as Gragson drove on with the lead and Allgaier slammed into the outside wall.

Gragson then held off a challenge from Chase Briscoe and Brandon Jones in an overtime finish for his second win of the season and of his career.

"I really apologize to Justin and his team. That's not how I want to race," Gragson said. "I saw that position open up when he slipped off the bottom. I tried to get to the bottom and I just got too loose. This track was like ice. Everyone was slipping and sliding."

Gragson, a 21-year-old from Las Vegas, won the final two stages of the race and led two times for 55 laps. He hadn't finished higher than ninth in five previous Bristol starts in the Xfinity and Truck Series.

"We had been terrible here in Trucks and then in Xfinity last year," Gragson said. "My crew chief (David Elenz) believed in me. He wanted me to come back and run with them this season."

Allgaier won Stage 1 of the race and led 156 laps overall. It was the third Bristol race in a row that he led the most laps and failed to win. He left the track after the race without a post-race interview.

Briscoe held on for second with Jones third and pole-sitter Harrison Burton fourth. Each of the top four finishers qualified for a chance to win a $100,000 Dash 4 Cash bonus in Saturday's race at Atlanta.

It was the second straight runner-up finish at Bristol for Briscoe, driver of the No. 98 Stewart-Haas Racing Ford.

"We had a fifth- or sixth-place car most of the night," Briscoe said. "We were really tight. There at the end, restarts went our way and we were able to salvage second."

Myatt Snider rounded out the top five in a Chevrolet. The rest of the top 10 were all in Chevys with Daniel Hemric sixth, followed by Brandon Brown, Jeremy Clements, Josh Williams and A.J. Allmendinger.

LOCAL CONNECTIONS

Knoxville driver Chad Finchum finished 24th in the No. 13 Toyota. The former Kingsport Speedway champion was 10th early in Stage 2 before having mechanical problems. Jesse Little, driving the No. 4 Visit Kingsport Chevrolet, ran in the top 15 early and finished 26th.

NASCAR STATEMENT

NASCAR released a statement Monday concerning the recent deaths that have sparked protests and riots in the following days.

It read, "The NASCAR family, like so many others, is hurt and angered by the immensely troubling events that have taken place across our country in recent weeks. For us to heal and move forward as a nation, we all need to listen more and be united in the stand against racism, hatred, senseless violence and loss of life. And we must all hold ourselves accountable to driving positive change.

"While our sport has made progress over the years, there remains much work to be done and we fully embrace our responsibility to help bridge the racial divide that continues to exist in our country. We must do better and our commitment to promoting equality and inclusion continues and will never waver."
